title: 103_hr4445
content: The Act is titled the "Rural Multifamily Rental Housing Loan Guarantee Demonstration Act" and it amends the Housing Act of 1949 to provide loan guarantees for multifamily rental housing in rural areas. The Secretary has the authority to guarantee eligible loans for housing development costs. The guarantee will cover up to 90% of the unpaid principal and interest of the loan. Eligible borrowers include nonprofit organizations, state agencies, and private entities. The loan must be used for housing development costs. The Secretary can guarantee loans for housing development costs, covering up to 90% of the loan. The housing must consist of 5 or more dwellings, be for low or moderate-income families, remain available as required, and be located in a rural area. A low-income housing tax credit may be provided. The Revenue Code of 1986 allows for a housing credit in connection with loans guaranteed under this section, provided the housing meets the Code's requirements. Eligible lenders must be approved by the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development or the Federal National Mortgage Association. The Secretary establishes a list of eligible lenders for the loan guarantee program under this section and conducts annual audits to ensure their eligibility. Loans guaranteed must provide for complete amortization. The loan guarantee program under this section shall involve complete amortization through periodic payments not exceeding 40 years, with an agreed fixed interest rate. The principal obligation should not exceed 97 percent of development costs for nonprofit organizations or government agencies. The loan guarantee program involves complete amortization through periodic payments not exceeding 40 years with a fixed interest rate. The principal obligation should not exceed 97 percent of development costs for nonprofit organizations or government agencies. Borrowers must secure the loan with a first mortgage on the housing and related facilities or as determined necessary by the Secretary for repayment. A guarantee fee is required at the time of loan issuance. The Secretary may collect a guarantee fee of up to 1 percent of the loan principal at issuance. Eligible lenders can issue certificates of guarantee without Secretary approval, subject to certain conditions. Payment under the guarantee is triggered by default. After default on a guaranteed loan, the holder must notify the Secretary and can initiate foreclosure proceedings. Upon court authorization for foreclosure, the holder is entitled to payment under the guarantee. After default on a guaranteed loan, the holder must notify the Secretary and can initiate foreclosure proceedings. The guarantee amount is paid upon conveyance of title to the security property, submission of a claim for payment, and assignment of all claims to the Secretary. The Secretary may accept assignment of the loan if it is in the best interests of the United States. Upon assignment of a loan under this paragraph, the holder of a guarantee certificate shall be entitled to payment by the Secretary under the guarantee. Before any payment is made, the holder must exhaust all collection possibilities. Upon payment, the debt shall be assigned to the United States and the holder will have no further claim against the borrower. The Secretary may require lenders to indemnify for losses if a guaranteed loan was not originated according to requirements. The lender must issue the guarantee certificate and the debt will be assigned to the United States with no further claim against the borrower. The Secretary may cancel a lender's authority to issue guarantees if they violate requirements or for good cause. Cancellation takes effect upon notice to the lender. The Secretary may cancel a lender's authority to issue guarantees for violations or good cause, with finality and no judicial review. Loans can be refinanced under prescribed terms, with no increase in amount or term. Borrowers remain liable for outstanding loan amounts even after property transfer. A study will determine geographical targeting effectiveness. The Secretary will require an independent entity to conduct a study on the utilization of loan guarantees in rural areas, with a report due within 90 days of enactment. Loan guarantees will be targeted to rural areas with the greatest need. The Secretary will determine which areas need guaranteed loans based on a study. Credit-Elsewhere Test does not apply to guarantees under this section. Housing standards from section 515(m) apply to facilities financed with guaranteed loans. The Secretary's authority to guarantee loans is subject to appropriations. The Secretary may guarantee loans up to $200,000,000 in each of fiscal years 1995 and 1996. A report must be submitted to Congress within 2 years of the enactment of the Rural Multifamily Rental Housing Loan Guarantee Demonstration Act detailing the loan guarantee program. The report required by the Rural Multifamily Rental Housing Loan Guarantee Demonstration Act must describe the types of borrowers, areas served, income levels of residents, number of dwelling units provided, financial assistance obtained, and use of low-income housing tax credits. It also analyzes the financial viability of the program. The report for the Rural Multifamily Rental Housing Loan Guarantee Demonstration Act must analyze the financial viability of the housing provided with guaranteed loans, assess the need for project-based rental assistance, include recommendations for program expansion, and provide any other relevant information as deemed appropriate by the Secretary. Definitions for "development cost" and "eligible lender" are also specified. The term 'eligible lender' is defined as a lender meeting specific requirements determined by the Secretary. Authorization of appropriations is provided for fiscal years 1995 and 1996 for loan guarantees under this section, with a termination date set for September 30, 1996.
